title: Ilya Sutskever
content:
{{Short description|Computer scientist (born 1986)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2023}} {{Use Canadian English|date=February 2023}} {{CS1 config|mode=cs1}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Ilya Sutskever | native_name = {{Nobold|{{Script/Hebrew|איליה סוצקבר}}
{{Lang|ru|Илья Суцкевер}}}} | birth_name = {{Lang|ru|Илья́ Ефи́мович Суцке́вер}}
Ilya Efimovich Sutskever | honorific_suffix = {{post-nominals|country=CAN|FRS|size=100%}} | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1986|12|08|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Nizhny Novgorod|Gorky]], Russian SFSR, Soviet Union{{Cite web |title=Heard It Through the AI {{!}} University of Toronto Magazine |url=https://magazine.utoronto.ca/people/alumni-donors/heard-it-through-the-ai-openai-ilya-sutskever/ |access-date=9 October 2022 |website=University of Toronto Magazine |date=28 September 2022 |language=en-US |archive-date=29 May 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230529042940/https://magazine.utoronto.ca/people/alumni-donors/heard-it-through-the-ai-openai-ilya-sutskever/ |url-status=live }}{{cite web |title=Season 1 Ep. 22 Ilya Sutskever |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fCoavgGZ64Y |via=YouTube |publisher=The Robot Brains Podcast |access-date=14 August 2022 |date=21 September 2021 |archive-date=1 May 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230501143736/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fCoavgGZ64Y |url-status=live }} | death_date = | death_place = | citizenship = Canadian, Israeli{{Cite news |date=May 17, 2024 |title=OpenAI’s Israeli co-founder departs as US gears up regulation |url=https://www.jns.org/edited-hold-fri-openais-israeli-co-founder-departs-as-us-gears-up-regulation/ |work=Jewish News Syndicate}} | fields = [[Computer science]] | workplaces = [[University of Toronto]]
[[Google Brain]]
[[OpenAI]] | education = [[Open University of Israel]]
[[University of Toronto]] ([[Bachelor of Science|BS]], [[Master of Science|MS]], [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]]) | doctoral_advisor = [[Geoffrey Hinton]]{{MathGenealogy}} | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = [[AlexNet]]
Co-founding [[OpenAI]]
Founding [[Safe Superintelligence Inc.|SSI Inc.]] | thesis_title = Training Recurrent Neural Networks | thesis_url = https://tspace.library.utoronto.ca/bitstream/1807/36012/6/Ilya_Sutskever_201306_PhD_thesis.pdf | thesis_year = 2013 | influences = | influenced = | awards = | religion = | signature = | website = {{Official URL}} }} '''Ilya Sutskever''' {{Post-nominals|country=GBR|FRS}} (born 8 December 1986) is a Canadian-Israeli-Russian [[computer scientist]] who specializes in [[machine learning]].{{Google scholar id}} Sutskever has made several major contributions to the field of [[deep learning]].{{Cite journal |last1=Krizhevsky |first1=Alex |last2=Sutskever |first2=Ilya |last3=Hinton |first3=Geoffrey E |date=2012 |title=ImageNet Classification with Deep Convolutional Neural Networks |url=https://proceedings.neurips.cc/paper/2012/hash/c399862d3b9d6b76c8436e924a68c45b-Abstract.html |journal=Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems |publisher=Curran Associates, Inc. |volume=25}}{{Cite journal |last1=Srivastava |first1=Nitish |last2=Hinton |first2=Geoffrey |last3=Krizhevsky |first3=Alex |last4=Sutskever |first4=Ilya |last5=Salakhutdinov |first5=Ruslan |date=2014 |title=Dropout: A Simple Way to Prevent Neural Networks from Overfitting |url=http://jmlr.org/papers/v15/srivastava14a.html |journal=Journal of Machine Learning Research |volume=15 |issue=56 |pages=1929–1958 |issn=1533-7928}}{{Cite journal |last1=Sutskever |first1=Ilya |last2=Vinyals |first2=Oriol |last3=Le |first3=Quoc V. |date=2014-12-08 |title=Sequence to sequence learning with neural networks |url=https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.5555/2969033.2969173 |journal=Proceedings of the 27th International Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems - Volume 2 |series=NIPS'14 |location=Cambridge, MA, USA |publisher=MIT Press |pages=3104–3112 |arxiv=1409.3215}} He is notably the co-inventor, with [[Alex Krizhevsky]] and [[Geoffrey Hinton]], of [[AlexNet]], a [[convolutional neural network]].{{cite Q|Q59445836}} Sutskever co-founded and is a former chief scientist at [[OpenAI]].{{cite news |last1=Metz |first1=Cade |title=A.I. Researchers Are Making More Than $1 Million, Even at a Nonprofit |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/19/technology/artificial-intelligence-salaries-openai.html?action=click&module=RelatedCoverage&pgtype=Article®ion=Footer |access-date=22 October 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=19 April 2018 |language=en |archive-date=1 March 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230301021221/https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/19/technology/artificial-intelligence-salaries-openai.html?action=click&module=RelatedCoverage&pgtype=Article®ion=Footer |url-status=live }} In 2023, he was one of the members of OpenAI's board that [[Removal of Sam Altman from OpenAI|ousted]] [[Sam Altman]] from his position as [[Chief executive officer|CEO]]; Altman returned a week later, and Sutskever stepped down from the board. In June 2024, Sutskever co-founded the company [[Safe Superintelligence]] with [[Daniel Gross (entrepreneur)|Daniel Gross]] and Daniel Levy.{{cite web |date=19 June 2024 |title=Safe Superintelligence Inc. |url=https://ssi.inc/ |access-date=19 June 2024 |website=SSI}}{{cite web |last1=Vance |first1=Ashlee |date=19 June 2024 |title=Ilya Sutskever Has a New Plan for Safe Superintelligence |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2024-06-19/openai-co-founder-plans-new-ai-focused-research-lab |access-date=19 June 2024 |website=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]]}} ==Early life and education== Sutskever was born into a [[Jews|Jewish]] family{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2024/05/16/russian-born-genius-chatgpt-openai-failed-coup-sam-altman |title=How ChatGPT’s Russian-born genius sealed his fate after a shocking coup |last=Titcomb |first=James |date=16 May 2024 |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |access-date=29 September 2024 |url-access=subscription}} in [[Nizhny Novgorod]], Russia (then Gorky, [[Soviet Union]]). At the age of 5, he made [[aliyah]] with his family and lived in [[Jerusalem]], Israel,{{Cite news |last=מן |first=יובל |date=2022-11-18 |title="הבינה המלאכותית מהמדע הבדיוני תהפוך למציאות" |language=he |work=Ynet |url=https://www.ynet.co.il/digital/technology/article/h1ebvhxuj |access-date=2023-04-18 |archive-date=18 April 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230418113604/https://www.ynet.co.il/digital/technology/article/h1ebvhxuj |url-status=live }}{{cite news |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/openai-co-founder-creates-a-new-ai-startup-with-a-research-lab-in-tel-aviv |title=OpenAI co-founder creates a new AI startup with a research lab in Tel Aviv |last=Wrobel |first=Sharon |date=20 June 2024 |website=[[The Times of Israel]] |access-date=29 September 2024 |url-access=subscription}} until he was 16, when his family moved to Canada.{{Cite web |last=Ansari |first=Tasmia |date=2023-03-07 |title=The Brain That Supercharged ChatGPT, ImageNet and TF |url=https://analyticsindiamag.com/the-brain-that-supercharged-chatgpt-imagenet-tensorflow/ |access-date=2023-03-14 |website=Analytics India Magazine |language=en-US |archive-date=14 March 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230314232358/https://analyticsindiamag.com/the-brain-that-supercharged-chatgpt-imagenet-tensorflow/ |url-status=live }} Sutskever attended the [[Open University of Israel]] from 2000 to 2002.{{cite web |title=Neural networking |url=https://thevarsity.ca/2010/10/25/neural-networking/ |website=The Varsity |access-date=14 August 2022 |date=25 October 2010 |archive-date=8 June 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200608205112/https://thevarsity.ca/2010/10/25/neural-networking/ |url-status=live }} After moving to Canada, he attended the [[University of Toronto]] in [[Ontario]]. Sutskever received a [[Bachelor of Science]] in [[mathematics]] from the University of Toronto in 2005,{{cite web |last1=Johnston |first1=Jessica Leigh |date=8 December 2010 |title=A Neural Network for a New Millennium |url=https://magazine.utoronto.ca/people/students/ilya-sutskever-google-phd-fellowship/ |access-date=14 August 2022 |website=University of Toronto Magazine |archive-date=14 April 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230414064407/https://magazine.utoronto.ca/people/students/ilya-sutskever-google-phd-fellowship/ |url-status=live }}{{LinkedIn user}} a [[Master of Science]] in [[computer science]] in 2007,{{cite thesis |last1=Sutskever |first1=Ilya |title=Nonlinear multilayered sequence models |year=2007 |hdl=1807/119676 |url=https://tspace.library.utoronto.ca/handle/1807/119676 |website=utoronto.ca |publisher=University of Toronto |oclc=234120052 |degree=MSc |language=en |access-date=24 March 2023 |archive-date=24 March 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230324150814/https://tspace.library.utoronto.ca/handle/1807/119676 |url-status=live }} and a [[Doctor of Philosophy]] in computer science in 2013.{{cite thesis |last1=Sutskever |first1=Ilya |title=Training Recurrent Neural Networks |year=2013 |hdl=1807/36012 |url=https://tspace.library.utoronto.ca/handle/1807/36012 |website=utoronto.ca |publisher=University of Toronto |id={{ProQuest|1501655550}} |oclc=889910425 |degree=PhD |language=en |access-date=24 March 2023 |archive-date=26 March 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230326022642/https://tspace.library.utoronto.ca/handle/1807/36012 |url-status=live }}{{cite web |title=RAM Workshop |url=http://www.thespermwhale.com/jaseweston/ram/ |access-date=14 August 2022 |website=thespermwhale.com |archive-date=5 December 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221205110829/http://www.thespermwhale.com/jaseweston/ram/ |url-status=dead }}{{cite web |title=Episode 85: A Conversation with Ilya Sutskever |url=https://voicesinai.com/episode/episode-85-a-conversation-with-ilya-sutskever/ |access-date=14 August 2022 |website=Voices in AI |publisher=Gigaom |archive-date=22 March 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230322223929/https://voicesinai.com/episode/episode-85-a-conversation-with-ilya-sutskever/ |url-status=live }} His doctoral supervisor was [[Geoffrey Hinton]]. In 2012, Sutskever built [[AlexNet]] in collaboration with Hinton and [[Alex Krizhevsky]]. To support AlexNet's computing demands, he bought many [[GTX 580]] GPUs online.{{Cite web |title=Exclusive: Ilya Sutskever, OpenAI's chief scientist, on his hopes and fears for the future of AI |url=https://www.technologyreview.com/2023/10/26/1082398/exclusive-ilya-sutskever-openais-chief-scientist-on-his-hopes-and-fears-for-the-future-of-ai/ |access-date=2023-11-01 |website=MIT Technology Review |language=en |archive-date=1 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231101193816/https://www.technologyreview.com/2023/10/26/1082398/exclusive-ilya-sutskever-openais-chief-scientist-on-his-hopes-and-fears-for-the-future-of-ai/ |url-status=live }} ==Career and research== [[File:Democratizing Deep Learning with Nervana and Google Brain (15105407149).jpg|thumb|Sutskever (second from right) at the Stanford Graduate School of Business in 2014]] In 2012, Sutskever spent about two months as a [[postdoc]] with [[Andrew Ng]] at [[Stanford University]]. He then returned to the University of Toronto and joined Hinton's new research company DNNResearch, a [[University spin-off|spinoff]] of Hinton's research group. In 2013, Google acquired DNNResearch and hired Sutskever as a research scientist at [[Google Brain]].{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/2013/03/google_hinton/|title=Google Hires Brains that Helped Supercharge Machine Learning|last=McMillan|first=Robert|date=13 March 2013|website=wired.com|access-date=9 November 2019|archive-date=16 June 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180616190308/https://www.wired.com/2013/03/google_hinton/|url-status=live}} At Google Brain, Sutskever worked with [[Oriol Vinyals]] and [[Quoc Viet Le]] to create the [[seq2seq|sequence-to-sequence]] learning algorithm, and worked on [[TensorFlow]].{{cite Q|Q29040034}} He is also one of the [[AlphaGo]] paper's many co-authors.{{cite Q|Q28005460}} At the end of 2015, Sutskever left Google to become cofounder and chief scientist of the newly founded organization [[OpenAI]]. {{cite web|title=OpenAI Blog|date=12 December 2015|url=https://www.openai.com/blog/introducing-openai/|access-date=17 July 2016|archive-date=6 October 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211006105333/https://openai.com/blog/introducing-openai/|url-status=dead}}{{Official URL}}{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/04/openai-elon-musk-sam-altman-plan-to-set-artificial-intelligence-free/|title=Inside OpenAI, Elon Musk's Wild Plan to Set Artificial Intelligence Free|last=Metz|first=Cade|date=27 April 2016|website=wire.com|access-date=9 November 2019|archive-date=27 April 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160427162700/http://www.wired.com/2016/04/openai-elon-musk-sam-altman-plan-to-set-artificial-intelligence-free/|url-status=live}} Sutskever is considered to have played a key role in the development of [[ChatGPT]].{{Cite web |last=Ansari |first=Tasmia |date=2023-03-07 |title=The Brain That Supercharged ChatGPT, ImageNet and TF |url=https://analyticsindiamag.com/the-brain-that-supercharged-chatgpt-imagenet-tensorflow/ |access-date=2024-05-17 |website=AIM |language=en-US}}{{Cite web |last=Heaven |first=Will Douglas |date=May 2, 2023 |title=Geoffrey Hinton tells us why he's now scared of the tech he helped build |url=https://www.technologyreview.com/2023/05/02/1072528/geoffrey-hinton-google-why-scared-ai/ |access-date=2024-05-17 |website=MIT Technology Review |language=en}} In 2023, he announced that he would co-lead OpenAI's new "Superalignment" project, which is trying to solve the [[AI alignment|alignment]] of [[superintelligence]]s within four years. He wrote that even if superintelligence seems far off, it could happen this decade.{{Cite web |title=Introducing Superalignment |url=https://openai.com/blog/introducing-superalignment |access-date=2023-07-14 |website=openai.com |language=en-US |archive-date=14 July 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230714160436/https://openai.com/blog/introducing-superalignment |url-status=live }} Sutskever was formerly one of the six board members of the nonprofit entity that controls OpenAI.{{cite web |title=Our structure |url=https://openai.com/our-structure |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230729203855/https://openai.com/our-structure |archive-date=29 July 2023 |access-date=2023-11-20 |quote=OpenAI is governed by the board of the OpenAI Nonprofit, composed of OpenAI Global, LLC employees Greg Brockman (Chairman & President), Ilya Sutskever (Chief Scientist), and Sam Altman (CEO), and non-employees Adam D’Angelo, Tasha McCauley, Helen Toner.}} On November 17, 2023, the board [[Removal of Sam Altman from OpenAI|fired Sam Altman]], saying that "he was not consistently candid in his communications with the board".{{Cite news |last=Metz |first=Cade |date=November 17, 2023 |title=OpenAI’s Board Pushes Out Sam Altman, Its High-Profile C.E.O. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/11/17/technology/openai-sam-altman-ousted.html |work=The New York Times}} [[The Information (website)|''The Information'']] speculated that the decision was partly driven by conflict over the extent to which the company should commit to [[AI safety]].{{Cite web |title=Before OpenAI Ousted Altman, Employees Disagreed Over AI 'Safety' |url=https://www.theinformation.com/articles/before-openai-ousted-altman-employees-disagreed-over-ai-safety |access-date=2023-11-20 |website=The Information |archive-date=18 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231118025046/https://www.theinformation.com/articles/before-openai-ousted-altman-employees-disagreed-over-ai-safety |url-status=live }} In an all-hands company meeting shortly after the board meeting, Sutskever said that firing Altman was "the board doing its duty",{{cite web|first1=Benj|last1=Edwards|access-date=2023-11-20|title=Details emerge of surprise board coup that ousted CEO Sam Altman at OpenAI|url=https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2023/11/report-sutskever-led-board-coup-at-openai-that-ousted-altman-over-ai-safety-concerns/|date=2023-11-18|website=Ars Technica|archive-date=19 November 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231119020114/https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2023/11/report-sutskever-led-board-coup-at-openai-that-ousted-altman-over-ai-safety-concerns/|url-status=live}} but the next week, he expressed regret at having participated in Altman's ouster.{{Cite news |last=Rosenberg |first=Scott |date=2023-11-20 |title=OpenAI's Sutskever says he regrets board's firing of Altman |work=Axios |url=https://www.axios.com/2023/11/20/sam-altman-fired-openai-board-illya-sutsever-regrets |access-date=2023-11-20}} Altman's firing and OpenAI's co-founder [[Greg Brockman|Greg Brockman's]] resignation led three senior researchers to resign from OpenAI.{{Cite web |last=Thompson |first=Polly |title=3 senior OpenAI researchers resign in the wake of Sam Altman's shock dismissal as CEO, report says |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/3-open-ai-researchers-resign-sam-altman-dismissal-ceo-2023-11 |access-date=2023-11-18 |website=Business Insider |language=en-US |archive-date=18 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231118180938/https://www.businessinsider.com/3-open-ai-researchers-resign-sam-altman-dismissal-ceo-2023-11 |url-status=live }} After that, Sutskever stepped down from the OpenAI board.{{Cite web |date=22 November 2023 |title=OpenAI announces return of Sam Altman as CEO. |url=https://x.com/OpenAI/status/1727206187077370115?s=20 }} After that, he was absent from OpenAI's office. Some sources suggested he was leading the team remotely, while others said he no longer had access to the team's work.{{Cite web |last=Kahn |first=Jeremy |date=May 21, 2024 |title=OpenAI promised 20% of its computing power to combat the most dangerous kind of AI—but never delivered, sources say |url=https://fortune.com/2024/05/21/openai-superalignment-20-compute-commitment-never-fulfilled-sutskever-leike-altman-brockman-murati/ |access-date=2024-05-22 |website=Fortune |language=en}} In May 2024, Sutskever announced his departure from OpenAI to focus on a new project that was "very personally meaningful" to him. His decision followed a turbulent period at OpenAI marked by leadership crises and internal debates about the direction of AI development and [[AI alignment|alignment]] protocols. [[Jan Leike]], the other leader of the superalignment project, announced his departure hours later, citing an erosion of safety and trust in OpenAI's leadership.{{Cite web |last=Samuel |first=Sigal |date=2024-05-17 |title="I lost trust": Why the OpenAI team in charge of safeguarding humanity imploded |url=https://www.vox.com/future-perfect/2024/5/17/24158403/openai-resignations-ai-safety-ilya-sutskever-jan-leike-artificial-intelligence |access-date=2024-05-18 |website=Vox |language=en}} In June 2024, Sutskever announced Safe Superintelligence Inc., a new company he founded with Daniel Gross and Daniel Levy with offices in [[Palo Alto]] and [[Tel Aviv]].{{cite news |last1=Tabassum |first1=Juveria |title=Former OpenAI chief scientist to start a new AI company |url=https://www.reuters.com/technology/artificial-intelligence/former-openai-chief-scientist-start-new-ai-company-2024-06-19/ |agency=Reuters |date=June 19, 2024}} In contrast to OpenAI, which releases revenue-generating products, Sutskever said the new company's "first product will be the safe superintelligence, and it will not do anything else up until then". In September 2024, the company announced that it had raised $1 billion from venture capital firms including [[Andreessen Horowitz]], [[Sequoia Capital]], [[DST Global]], and [[SV Angel]].{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/technology/artificial-intelligence/openai-co-founder-sutskevers-new-safety-focused-ai-startup-ssi-raises-1-billion-2024-09-04/|title=OpenAI co-founder Sutskever's new safety-focused AI startup SSI raises $1 billion|last1=Kai|first1=Kenrick|last2=Hu|first2=Krystal|last3=Tong|first3=Anna|date=4 September 2024|website=reuters.com|access-date=4 September 2024}} In an October 2024 interview after winning the [[Nobel Prize in Physics]], Geoffrey Hinton expressed support for Sutskever's decision to fire Altman, emphasizing concerns about AI safety.{{Cite web |last=Hetzner |first=Christiaan |title=New Nobel Prize winner, AI godfather Geoffrey Hinton, says he’s proud his student fired OpenAI boss Sam Altman |url=https://fortune.com/2024/10/09/openai-sam-altman-geoffrey-hinton-nobel-prize-physics-ilya-sutskever-toronto/ |access-date=2024-10-12 |website=Fortune |language=en}}{{Cite web |last=Tan |first=Kwan Wei Kevin |title=The Nobel Prize-winning 'godfather of AI' says he's glad one of his students had a hand in ousting Sam Altman from OpenAI |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/geoffrey-hinton-proud-student-fired-sam-altman-openai-2024-10 |access-date=2024-10-12 |website=Business Insider |language=en-US}} ===Awards and honors=== * In 2015, Sutskever was named in [[MIT Technology Review]]'s 35 Innovators Under 35.{{cite web|title=35 Innovators Under 35: Ilya Sutskever|url=https://www.technologyreview.com/lists/innovators-under-35/2015/visionary/ilya-sutskever/|website=technologyreview.com|access-date=17 July 2016|archive-date=4 May 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190504083506/https://www.technologyreview.com/lists/innovators-under-35/2015/visionary/ilya-sutskever/|url-status=live}} * In 2018, he was the keynote speaker at [[Nvidia]] Ntech 2018{{cite web |last1=Martin |first1=Scott |title=Reinforcement Learning 'Really Works' for AI Against Pro Gamers, OpenAI Trailblazer Says |url=https://blogs.nvidia.com/blog/2018/09/14/reinforcement-learning-openai-pro-gamers-ilya-sutskeverai-elon-musk-gpu-dgx/ |access-date=28 March 2023 |website=Nvidia Blog |date=15 September 2018 |publisher=Nvidia |archive-date=28 March 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230328141735/https://blogs.nvidia.com/blog/2018/09/14/reinforcement-learning-openai-pro-gamers-ilya-sutskeverai-elon-musk-gpu-dgx/ |url-status=live }} and AI Frontiers Conference 2018.{{Cite web |title=The man who revolutionized computer vision, machine translation, games and robotics · AI Frontiers Conference |url=https://aifrontiers.com/2018/08/29/the-journey-of-openais-founder-ilya-sutskever-s-story/ |access-date=2023-06-16 |website=aifrontiers.com |archive-date=16 June 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230616151350/https://aifrontiers.com/2018/08/29/the-journey-of-openais-founder-ilya-sutskever-s-story/ |url-status=live }} * In 2022, he was elected a [[Fellow of the Royal Society]] (FRS).{{Cite web|title=Ilya Sutskever|url=https://royalsociety.org/people/ilya-sutskever-35834/|access-date=12 May 2022|website=royalsociety.org|publisher=[[Royal Society]]|location=London|author=Anon|year=2022|archive-date=15 March 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230315060950/https://royalsociety.org/people/ilya-sutskever-35834/|url-status=live}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Wikiquote}} {{OpenAI navbox}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sutskever, Ilya}} [[Category:1985 births]] [[Category:OpenAI people]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Nizhny Novgorod]] [[Category:Canadian computer scientists]] [[Category:Canadian expatriates in the United States]] [[Category:Canadian fellows of the Royal Society]] [[Category:Canadian people of Russian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Israeli expatriates in the United States]] [[Category:Israeli people of Russian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Russian expatriates in the United States]] [[Category:Artificial intelligence researchers]] [[Category:Google employees]] [[Category:Machine learning researchers]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society]] [[Category:University of Toronto alumni]] [[Category:Stanford University alumni]] [[Category:AI safety scientists]]
